Definition.WordDefinition:
Salvo \Sal"vo\, n.; pl. {Salvos}. [L. salvo jure, literally, the right being reserved. See {Safe.}] An exception; a reservation; an excuse. [1913 Webster]
They admit many salvos, cautions, and reservations. --Eikon Basilike. [1913 Webster]

Dictionary.Name: The Collaborative International Dictionary of English v.0.44

Definition.WordDefinition:
Salvo \Sal"vo\, n. [F. salve a discharge of heavy cannon, a volley, L. salve hail, imperat. of salvere to be well, akin to salvus well. See {Safe}.] 1. (Mil.) A concentrated fire from pieces of artillery, as in endeavoring to make a break in a fortification; a volley. [1913 Webster]
2. A salute paid by a simultaneous, or nearly simultaneous, firing of a number of cannon. [1913 Webster]

salvo n 1: an outburst resembling the discharge of firearms or the release of bombs 2: rapid simultaneous discharge of firearms; "our fusillade from the left flank caught them by surprise" [syn: {fusillade}, {volley}, {burst}] 3: a sudden outburst of cheers; "there was a salvo of approval" [also: {salvoes} (pl)]
